audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a jaunty jazz tune, giving off a playful, cheerful vibe, prominently featuring a trumpet. This is followed by a male speaker welcoming listeners to a "physics vodcast", introducing the topic of "Newton's rings" and crediting Sir Isaac Newton. The music then returns briefly.

The audio clip features a male speaker who mentions that the podcast will respond to two questions about optics emailed by "Kaitlyn." He describes the first question, which concerns the relationship between the curvature of a convex lens and the size of the rings in an experiment she tried at home. Then, he transitions to describing the second question, concerning the effect of different colors on the rings' size and intensity. He suggests starting by looking at the configuration, noting that textbooks have representations of the setup. He invites listeners to check out textbooks and search the web for different representations. Finally, he asks what the reality of the configuration looks like.

The audio clip features a male speaker describing a magnifying glass, noting its flat edge, curved side, and a plate beneath. He explains how an experiment would be set up, placing the lens on top of the plate with the curved side down. The clip concludes with an ominous sound effect.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing an experiment, mentioning that a certain person "tried this and saw nothing." He then notes that the object of the experiment doesn't resemble pictures or diagrams in books, but that one can see something interesting "if you just get the light right and the angle," and look carefully. He suggests pressing down on a lens to observe this phenomenon. The clip ends abruptly with no clear conclusion.

The audio clip consists of a single male speaker who calmly and informatively describes a small dark dot that can be seen when a lens touches a glass plate, suggesting how to view it better with a magnifying glass or microscope. There are no other discernible sounds.

The audio clip begins with one male speaker discussing curvature, mentioning "Caitlin's question" and suggesting the use of a magnifying glass. The speaker demonstrates placing the glass on top and looking carefully, explaining that a dot will be visible, and that the dot associated with one item will be larger than the dot associated with another. The speaker then anticipates a question, stating "How can we see Newton's rings easily?"

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a paperweight that produces Newton's rings. He details its construction with metal rings, thumbscrews, and two pieces of glass, one flat and the other slightly curved. The speaker then explains how adjusting the knobs creates visible rings that can be brought into the light. Concluding the description, the speaker identifies them as "Newton's rings." Subsequently, the clip transitions to a brief musical interlude with a dark, droning tone, possibly electronic in nature.

The clip begins with a calm male speaker introducing the investigation of Caitlin's question about the size of rings under different colored lights. He then details the setup of the experiment, mentioning the use of laser pointers of different colors, which are mounted on a tripod, and the light being filtered through paper. He describes a thick glass plate at the back used to hold up the apparatus, explaining that it is used to provide an angle for viewing Newton's rings.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker setting up a demonstration with a laser, mentioning "Newton's Rings," and acknowledging the challenge of capturing the demonstration on video due to light levels. He explains plans to take photographs with red, green, and blue lasers and then plans to move a piece of paper and illuminate the rings with laser light, then a white light from a desk lamp, to compare the effects of laser light versus white light on the rings.

The clip opens with a single male speaker, showcasing his photography work. Speaking in a neutral tone, he presents various images illuminated with white light, detailing different colored rings. The speaker then transitions to discussing colored laser lights, red, green, and blue, noting how the rings appear smaller with different colors. He elaborates on an experiment involving half white light and half laser light, pointing out that the laser-illuminated rings align with the rings formed by the white light. He concludes his presentation, hoping the listeners can see what happened in his experiments.

The clip starts with a male speaker revisiting someone called Caitlin's questions, explaining the relationship between curvature and ring size, and how the rings can be made large and visible with minimal curvature. Next, he talks about the effect of different colored lights, describing how the rings shift, and how the lines line up under white light.  He praises the questions and encourages further research.  He hopes listeners enjoyed the podcast, and thanks Caitlin. As his speech ends, music with a jazzy style begins, featuring instruments like a trumpet and what sounds like clarinet.
